facts.text: This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali, J. This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari.

facts.text: The appellant was one of the persons who had filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was one of the persons who had filed numberination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.

facts.text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that constituency took up for scrutiny the nomination papers filed by the various candidates.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that companystituency took up for scrutiny the numberination papers filed by the various candidates

facts.text: On the same day, the Returning Officer rejected the appellant's nomination paper on certain grounds.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day he rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds which need number be set out as they are number material to the point raised in this appeal.

facts.text: The appellant moved the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon moved the High companyrt under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his numberination paper

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the appellant's application on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: and to direct the Returning Officer to include his name in the list of valid numberinations to be published. The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The appellant's contention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is incorrect and not affected by article 329(b) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is number companyrect that the view expressed by the High Court is number affected by article 329 b  of the Constitution and that he was entitled to a writ of certiorari in the circumstances of the case.

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismisses the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

facts.text: Besides the Madras High Court, seven other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 to entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have numberjurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of numberination papers.

facts.text: The Returning Officer scrutinized nomination papers under section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Scrutiny of numberination papers and their rejection are provided for in selection 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

facts.text: Parliament passed the Representation of the People Act, 1951 under article 327 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Representation of the People Act, 1951, which was passed by Parliament under article 327 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Section 100 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 provides improper rejection of nomination paper as a ground for declaring an election void.

anchor.surface_text: in section 100 of Representation of the People Act, 1951, one of the grounds for declaring an election to be void is the improper rejection of a numberination paper.

issues.text: the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b

anchor.surface_text: As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning.

issues.text: the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question

anchor.surface_text: and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question. The appellants case is that questioning something which has happened before a candidate is declared elected is number the same thing as questioning an election,

issues.text: that the conclusion arrived by the High Court does number follow from the language of article 329 b of the Constitution, whether that article is read by itself or along with the other articles in Part XV of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Broadly speaking, the arguments on which the judgment of the High Court is assailed are two fold -  1  that the conclusion arrived by the High Court does number follow from the language of article 329 b  of the Constitution, whether that article is read by itself or along with the other articles in Part XV of the Constitution and  2  that the anomalies which will arise if the construction put by the High Court on article 329 b  is accepted,

issues.text: that the anomalies which will arise if the construction put by the High Court on article 329 b is accepted, are so startling that the courts should lean in favour of the construction put forward on behalf of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the anomalies which will arise if the construction put by the High Court on article 329 b  is accepted, are so startling that the courts should lean in favour of the construction put forward on behalf of the appellant. The first argument which turns on the construction of article 329 b  requires serious consideration, but I think the second argument can be disposed of briefly at the outset.

issues.text: section 36 of Act XLIII of 1951 would be ultra vires inasmuch as it confers on the Returning Officer a jurisdiction which article 329 b confers on a Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that if nomination is part of election, a dispute as to the validity of nomination is a dispute relating to election and that can be called in question only in accordance with the provisions of article 329 b  by the presentation of an election petition to the appropriate Tribunal and that the Returning Officer would have no jurisdiction to decide that matter, and it was further argued that section 36 of Act XLIII of 1951 would be ultra vires inasmuch as it confers on the Returning Officer a jurisdiction which article 329 b  confers on a Tribunal to be appointed in accordance with the article.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned here that the question as to what the powers of the High Court under article 226 and 227 and of this Court under article 136 of the Constitution may be, is one that will have to be decided on a proper occasion.

arguments.claim: Word 'election' in Part XV and Art 329(b) has wide meaning denoting entire process culminating in candidate declaration.

anchor.surface_text: the word election has been used in Part XV of the Constitution in the wide sense, that is to say, to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected In Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami

arguments.claim: Part XV of Constitution and ROPA 1951 form self-contained code; disputes only via election petition after election.

anchor.surface_text: Part XV of the Constitution, the heading of which is Elections, and it runs as follows Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution ... The Representation of the People Act, 1951, which was passed by Parliament under article 327 of the Constitution, makes detailed provisions

arguments.claim: Where statute creates right/liability and special remedy, that remedy exclusive; applies to election law.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well-recognized that where a right or liability is created by a statute which gives a special remedy for enforcing it, the remedy provided by that statute only must be availed of.

arguments.claim: Article 329(b) 'notwithstanding anything in this Constitution' excludes High Court Art 226 jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Representation of the People Act, 1951, which was passed by Parliament under article 327 of the Constitution, A noticeable difference in the language used in article 327 and 328 on the one hand, and article 329 on the other, is that while the first two articles begin with the words subject to the provisions of this Constitution.

arguments.claim: English election law similar; improper nomination rejection challenged only by election petition, not writs.

anchor.surface_text: it has never been held in England that the improper rejection of a nomination paper can be the subject of a writ of certiorari or mandamus. On the other hand, it was conceded at the bar that the question of improper rejection of a nomination paper has always been brought up

arguments.claim: Election disputes postponed till after to avoid delay; no intermediate court challenges.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the important functions which the legislature have to perform in democratic countries, it has always been recognized to be a matter of first importance that elections should be concluded as early as possible

arguments.claim: Seven other High Courts held no Art 226 jurisdiction for improper nomination rejection.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers.

holdings.text: The word 'election' in Article 329(b) and Part XV of the Constitution has been used in the wide sense, to connote the entire process culminating in the declaration of a candidate as elected.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the word election has been used in Part XV of the Constitution in the wide sense, that is to say, to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected In Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long usage in democratic contexts gives wide and narrow meanings; precedents like Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami adopt wide sense; consistent with 'conduct of elections' in Art 324 and overall Part XV scheme.

holdings.text: Questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper is comprehended within 'no election shall be called in question' under Article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: I think it follows by necessary implication from the language of this provision that those grounds cannot be urged in any other manner, at any other stage and before any other court. If the grounds on which an election can be called in question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper rejection is a ground under s.100 ROPA for voiding election; can only be raised via election petition post-election, not intermediately; aligns with election law scheme postponing disputes.

holdings.text: Article 329(b), beginning with 'notwithstanding anything in this Constitution', excludes High Court jurisdiction under Article 226 to interfere with Returning Officer's order rejecting nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: A noticeable difference in the language used in article 327 and 328 on the one hand, and article 329 on the other, is that while the first two articles begin with the words subject to the provisions of this Constitution. the last article begins with the words notwithstanding anything in this Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrast with 'subject to' in Arts 327/328; mirrors s.80 ROPA; historical English law and prior Indian rules exclude writs; self-contained code in Part XV and ROPA.

holdings.text: Hardships or anomalies from exclusive election petition remedy do not override the plain language and scheme of Article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: if the construction put by the High Court on article 329 b  of the Constitution is found to be correct, the fact that such construction will lead to hardship and inconvenience becomes irrelevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hardship is secondary to correct construction; public interest in timely elections outweighs individual prejudice; English practice recognizes no immediate relief.

holdings.text: Section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is not ultra vires; Returning Officer's scrutiny of nominations is a stage in the election process, not questioning the election.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, it is the duty of the Returning Officer to scrutinize the nomination papers to ensure that they comply with the requirements of the Act and decide all objections which be made to any nomination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RO performs administrative duty to ensure compliance before election completes; equates single step to whole election is fallacy; disputes on validity via petition only.

holdings.text: The view of the Madras High Court and seven other State High Courts that there is no jurisdiction under Article 226 for improper rejection of nomination papers is correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers. This view is in my opinion correct and must be affirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent judicial interpretation across High Courts aligns with constitutional scheme and election law.

holdings.text: The question of powers of High Courts under Articles 226/227 and Supreme Court under Article 136 in election matters is not decided here.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned here that the question as to what the powers of the High Court under article 226 and 227 and of this Court under article 136 of the Constitution may be, is one that will have to be decided on a proper occasion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deferred for proper occasion; not necessary for this appeal.

It is n

precedents.case_name: Sarvothama Rao v Chairman Municipal Council Saidapet
precedents.cited_proposition: post-election remedy is inadequate; election should be stayed for rejected nomination
precedents.cited_holding: any post election remedy is wholly inadequate to afford the relief... injunction staying this election was absolutely necessary

anchor.surface_text: the other side of the picture in a subsequent case  Desi Chettiar v. Chinnasami Chettiar  1928  A.I.R. Mad. 1271 AT 1272   in the following passage - The petitioner is no without his remedy. His remedy lies in an election petition which we understand he has already put in. It is argued for him that remedy which merely allows him to have set aside an election once held is no as efficacious as the one which would enable him to stop the election altogether and certain observations at p. 600 of Sarvothama Rao v. Chairman, Municipal Council, Saidapet   1924  I.L.R. 47 Mad. 585 AT 600  are quoted.

precedents.cited_proposition: election petition is adequate remedy; no right to writ to stop election
precedents.cited_holding: The petitioner is no without his remedy. His remedy lies in an election petition... these observations were directed to the consideration of the propriety of an injunction in a civil suit

precedents.citation: Sarvothama Rao v. Chairman, Municipal Council, Saidapet   1924  I.L.R. 47 Mad. 585 AT 600

anchor.surface_text: certain observations at p. 600 of Sarvothama Rao v. Chairman, Municipal Council, Saidapet   1924  I.L.R. 47 Mad. 585 AT 600  are quoted. In the first place, we do no see how the mere fact that the petitioner cannot get the election stopped and has his remedy only after it is over by an election petition, will in itself confer on him any right to obtain a writ.

precedents.case_name: Sarvothama Rao v Chairman Municipal Council Saidapet
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on inadequacy distinguished as pertaining to injunction in civil suit

precedents.citation: Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami   1928  A.I.R. Mad. 253 at 255

anchor.surface_text: In Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami   1928  A.I.R. Mad. 253 at 255 , the learned Judges of the madras High Court after examining the question, expressed the opinion that the term election may be taken to embrace the whole procedure whereby an elected member is returned, whether or no it be found necessary to take a poll.

precedents.cited_proposition: election embraces the whole procedure of returning a member
precedents.cited_holding: the term election may be taken to embrace the whole procedure whereby an elected member is returned

precedents.citation: Sat Narain v. Hanuman Prasad   1945  A.I.R. Lah. 85

anchor.surface_text: With this view, my brother, Mahajan J expressed his agreement in Sat Narain v. Hanuman Prasad   1945  A.I.R. Lah. 85  and I also find myself in agreement with it.

precedents.cited_proposition: agreement with wide meaning of election

precedents.citation: Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford  6 C.B.  N.S.  336, 356

anchor.surface_text: This rule was stated with great clarity by Willes J. in Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford  6 C.B.  N.S.  336, 356  in the following passage - There are three classes of cases in which a liability may be established founded upon statute.

precedents.case_name: Wolverhampton New Water Works Co v Hawkesford
precedents.cited_proposition: where statute creates liability and provides special remedy, that remedy must be followed
precedents.cited_holding: The remedy provided by the statute must be followed, and it is no competent to the party to pursue the course applicable to cases of the second class.

precedents.citation: Neville v. London Express News Paper Limited  1919  A.C. 368.

anchor.surface_text: The rule laid down in this passage was approved by the House of Lords in Neville v. London Express News Paper Limited  1919  A.C. 368.  and has been reaffirmed by the Privy Council in Attorney-General of Trinidad and Tobago v. Gordons Grant Co.   1935  A.C. 532

precedents.case_name: Neville v London Express Newspaper Limited
precedents.cited_proposition: approval of rule on statutory remedies
